critiques.title: No prerequisite check for swiftc in install.sh
critiques.description: The install script runs swiftc without checking if it's available. On a stock macOS without Xcode or CLT, this fails with a cryptic 'command not found' error.
critiques.resolution: Valid but lower priority than Xcode license check (U-07). Still worth adding a prerequisite check.

critiques.title: No Homebrew installation option
critiques.description: The tool requires git clone + script execution rather than brew install.
critiques.resolution: Initially rated as major barrier; downgraded after critique. One extra step for target audience. Nice-to-have for adoption/discoverability.

critiques.title: Unbounded log growth with no retention policy
critiques.description: Log files rotate at 50 MB but old files are never deleted. Over time, logs accumulate without bound.
critiques.resolution: Valid principle (set-and-forget tools should self-clean). Urgency overstated -- practical growth is ~2-4 MB/month. Still a real concern for long-running deployments.

critiques.title: No health check mechanism for the daemon
critiques.description: No status script, no heartbeat log, no way to verify the daemon is alive and logging correctly.
critiques.resolution: Ranked #4 in revised priority list. A status.sh script or periodic heartbeat event would address this.

critiques.title: Silent log write failures when fileHandle is nil
critiques.description: LogWriter.write() silently drops events when fileHandle is nil. Combined with try? on line 16, the daemon can appear running but log nothing.
critiques.resolution: Critique correctly pinpointed try? on line 16 as the root cause. Ranked #2 in revised priority.

critiques.title: No versioning, releases, or changelogs
critiques.description: No version string, no git tags, no GitHub releases, no CHANGELOG. Users cannot pin versions or report issues against specific releases.
critiques.resolution: Essential for any open source project. Minimum: add a version constant and git tags.

critiques.title: Xcode license agreement failure mode not handled
critiques.description: On fresh Xcode installs, swiftc fails with 'Agreeing to the Xcode/iOS license requires admin privileges' error. More common than swiftc-not-found.
critiques.resolution: New issue from critique. Install script should check for this condition. Part of broader prerequisite check improvement.

critiques.title: sed tilde expansion in install.sh is fragile
critiques.description: The sed substitution for expanding ~ only handles one specific path pattern. Special characters in INSTALL_DIR would break it.
critiques.resolution: Theoretically fragile but practically unlikely to fail with standard home directories. Should be noted but not prioritized.

critiques.title: try? on directory creation masks failures silently
critiques.description: try? FileManager.default.createDirectory silently ignores directory creation failures, leading to nil fileHandle and silent data loss.
critiques.resolution: Root cause of U-05. Should use try with proper error reporting.

critiques.title: Process snapshot captured but never displayed by analyzer
critiques.description: Anomaly events include processSnapshot data (captured at swift:159-164) but analyze_anomalies() never displays it. The most valuable forensic data is hidden.
critiques.resolution: Consensus #1 usability fix. ~10 lines to add to analyze_anomalies(). Broken feature, not missing feature.

critiques.title: Histogram bar capped at 50 characters, visually misleading
critiques.description: The # histogram bars are capped at 50 chars regardless of count. An app with 51 activations looks identical to one with 5000.
critiques.resolution: Minor visual issue. Should use proportional scaling or note the cap.

critiques.title: No color output in analyzer
critiques.description: Plain text output with no ANSI color coding for different event types.
critiques.resolution: Nice-to-have but requires terminal detection for piping compatibility.

critiques.title: No relative timestamps in --last mode
critiques.description: All timestamps are absolute ISO8601. In --last mode, relative times ('2 minutes ago') would be more intuitive.
critiques.resolution: Good UX improvement for the time-filtered analysis modes.

critiques.title: Privacy/security implications underdocumented
critiques.description: The daemon logs every app focus change and periodic ps output. No privacy section in README discussing data collection, storage, access control, or implications.
critiques.resolution: Initially listed as documentation gap; upgraded to high severity. Needs prominent README section.

critiques.title: No upgrade path or mechanism
critiques.description: No version check, no migration path, no documented upgrade procedure. Contradicted by daemon design (KeepAlive, auto-start) which implies long-lived usage.
critiques.resolution: Valid for long-lived usage. Claude's 'temporary tool' defense weakened by the daemon's persistent design.

critiques.title: Contribution workflow impractical without Package.swift
critiques.description: No Xcode project or Package.swift. Contributors must use text editors without IDE support. Adding Package.swift is ~15 lines for substantial improvement.
critiques.resolution: Negligible cost, significant benefit. Should be added.

critiques.title: No user-facing notifications for anomalies
critiques.description: Anomalies are silently logged with no macOS notification or alert. Users must actively run the analyzer.
critiques.resolution: Potentially scope creep per self-review. Design philosophy is passive logging. Valid user expectation but changes tool character.

critiques.title: No sample output or screenshots in README
critiques.description: README describes analyzer output but doesn't show it. No screenshots, GIFs, or sample terminal output.
critiques.resolution: Standard open source practice. Sample output would significantly help evaluation.

critiques.title: No troubleshooting section in README
critiques.description: No guidance on what to do when things go wrong -- daemon not starting, logs not appearing, compilation failures.
critiques.resolution: Should cover the top 3-5 failure scenarios.

critiques.title: No real-time log following mode in analyzer
critiques.description: No --follow or --watch mode for live monitoring. Users investigating active focus theft must use workarounds like tail -f.
critiques.resolution: New issue from rebuttal. Natural expectation for a diagnostic tool.

critiques.title: Plist stderr/stdout go to /tmp, lost on reboot
critiques.description: StandardOutPath and StandardErrorPath point to /tmp/ which is cleared on macOS reboot. Daemon error diagnostics are lost across reboots.
critiques.resolution: New issue from rebuttal. Should point to ~/Library/Logs/attention-thief-catcher/ for persistence.

critiques.title: Naive datetime in analyze.py --last mode
critiques.description: datetime.now() returns naive datetime while log timestamps strip timezone info. Could produce confusing results if timezone changes.
critiques.resolution: Self-review correctly noted this is theoretical. Low practical likelihood for primary use case.

critiques.title: No tests, CI, or contribution guidelines
critiques.description: Zero test coverage, no GitHub Actions, no CONTRIBUTING.md, no issue/PR templates.
critiques.resolution: Barrier to contributions and code quality confidence. Package.swift (U-16) would enable test infrastructure.

critiques.title: Privacy comparison to shell history is misleading
critiques.description: Claude's hedge that logged data is 'not more sensitive than shell history' understates the privacy implications. Passive activity logging is more invasive than user-initiated command recording.
critiques.resolution: Rebuttal point accepted. Privacy section should not minimize the surveillance profile.
